item.content:encoded: NYT: Google to Sell Heads-Up Display Glasses By Year’s End - http://t.co/qLWfURAJ Google is currently making a pair of glasses that will be able to stream information to the wearer's eyes in real time. item.title: Flickr Is Getting a Major Makeover | Betabeat — News, gossip and intel from Silicon Alley 2.0.
item.description: Flickr Is Getting a Major Makeover via @Betabeat http://t.co/ve7TpGw2
item.content:encoded: Flickr Is Getting a Major Makeover via @Betabeat http://t.co/ve7TpGw2 Markus Spiering has, as they say, a good eye. Most of his resume was in mobile before he became a senior product manager for Flickr. In March 2011, he slipped into the head product role, lording over Flickr’s 45 or so employees. “”I have the pleasure to run product management for one of the most exciting web sites in the world: Flickr,” he says on his website. He’s in town for the Photo Hack Day hackathon this weekend, the first small sign of what could be the company’s reinvigorated interest in its audience. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: betabeat.com

item.title: John Paton to news execs: Abandon the gatekeeper model
item.description: John Paton to news execs: Abandon the gatekeeper model http://t.co/OAF10xjF
item.content:encoded: John Paton to news execs: Abandon the gatekeeper model http://t.co/OAF10xjF If there was an Uncle Sam-style campaign to recruit media executives into the “digital first” movement, John Paton would probably win the role of poster boy in a landslide. Even before he became the CEO of the giant MediaNews Group chain, Paton was calling on the media industry to give up its attachment to print and embrace the web and digital media — and he reiterated that message in a fire-and-brimstone speech to a journalism group in Toronto, Ontario recently. The bottom line, according to Paton, is that the time for deliberation is over: media entities of all kinds must give up the “information gatekeeper” model, he said, or they will surely perish. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: gigaom.com

item.title: 3 Ways To Predict What Consumers Want Before They Know It | Co.Design: business + innovation + design
item.description: 3 Ways To Predict What Consumers Want Before They Know It http://t.co/qOF4cK0r @FastCoDesign via @jeffswystun
item.content:encoded: 3 Ways To Predict What Consumers Want Before They Know It http://t.co/qOF4cK0r @FastCoDesign via @jeffswystun The insight that sparks innovation appears to occur randomly. After all, the iconic shorthand for innovation is a light bulb, implying that ideas come from sudden flashes of inspiration. While such flashes are surely good things, it is hard to depend on them, particularly if you are at a company that needs to introduce a steady stream of innovative ideas. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: fastcodesign.com

item.title: Hurdles Remain Before College Classrooms Go Completely Digital
item.description: Hurdles Remain Before College Classrooms Go Completely Digital http://t.co/vyML2dKP
item.content:encoded: Hurdles Remain Before College Classrooms Go Completely Digital http://t.co/vyML2dKP OnlineUniversities.com came out with an optimistic infographic last week about How College Classrooms Are Going Digital. But as someone who makes as much of a quarter of his income from teaching college classes in any given year, and who also spends a good amount of time speaking at conferences trying to help professors incorporate technology and social media into their curriculum, the view from the trenches is very different than the iPad-in-every-backpack proponents would have you believe. This is not to say that tech isn't changing the way we teach and the way students learn: it most certainly is. But... Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: readwriteweb.com
